comms: meenutama can mean both 'to resemble' and 'to recall', so without a context, the Estonian translation is ambiguous
võitma 'to win (a game); to beat (someone in a game)' - I wasn't sure which translation (win/beat) to use in the glosses
instead of väljuma, one could also say välja minema (välja 'out', minema 'to go')
another possibility would be to use the verb karjatama 'to drive to pasture'
back_translation_en: ‘Pearu is driving the cow to the pasture.’
‘Pearu is holding the book in his hands.’

comms: Pearu mõtleb Maarjale (ALL instead of ELA) is also possible, so the y-argument could be analysed as ELA~ALL

back_translation_en: ‘Pearu got to know Maarja a year ago.’

comms: jääma 'to stay' and ilma 'without'; ilma jääma 'to loose' (lit. something like 'to be left without'). There is also kaotama 'to loose', but in this context, ilma jääma sounds more natural
I had a hard time glossing kinni 'closed; shut; attached' (adverb) as it doesn't seem to have a fitting English translation
back_translation_en: ‘Pearu is trying to catch the cat.’
‘Pearu is dreaming of a new car.’

comms: the verb kutsuma translates as 'to call' (not 'to be called'); here the impersonal is used (just like in Finnish)
back_translation_en: ‘This measuring tool is called a compass.’

comms: perhaps a bit more common in colloquial speech: Pearul on üks euro puudu. (< puudu 'missing' + olema 'to be')
how literal should the back-translation be?
I decided to spell out the number to show that it is in the nominative case (the following noun eurot is in the partitive, which is triggered by the preceding number)

sentence: Ei, minu särk erine-b sinu oma-st.

comms: I used vigastama 'to hurt' instead of lõikama 'to cut' here, because Pearu lõikas ennast 'Pearu cut himself (partitive)' would leave the impression that the cutting was done on purpose, while vigastama does not have the same connotation. Another solution would be Pearu lõikas endale ... 'Pearu cut himself (allative) ...', but in this case we'd need to specify where he cut himself to make it sound natural, e.g. kätte 'into his hand'.

back_translation_en: ‘The glass got stuck to the table.’

comms: also possible and neutral: Maarja-l sündi-s poeg. PN-ADESS be_born-PST.3SG son.SG.NOM, lit. 'To Maarja a son was born'
in general, kuulama 'to listen' requires the partitive, the genitive/nominative only occurs with particles or resultative complements like ära or lõpuni 'to the end'
sõna is a noun, not a postposition (unlike kUlge, Ule, suhtes, etc.)
sentence: Pearu kuula-b alati oma ema sõna.
glosses_en: PN.SG.NOM listen-PRS.3SG always POSS.REFL mother.SG.GEN word.SG.PART
back_translation_en: ‘Pearu always listens to his mother's word.’
‘The honey got mixed with the milk.’

comms: like kuulama, vaatama 'to look/watch' requires the partitive, unless there is some kind of particle (üle 'over', läbi 'through', lõpuni 'to the end' etc)

back_translation_en: ‘Pearu got into a quarrel with Maarja.’

comms: like that, the sentence does not contain information on whether P. missed the bird or not

sentence: Pearu on musta-de nõu-de suhtes pirtsakas.
glosses_en: PN.SG.NOM be.PRS.3SG dirty-PL.GEN dish-PL.GEN about squeamish

sentence: Pearu ol-i selle kingituse üle üllatu-nud.
glosses_en: PN.SG.NOM be-PST.3SG DEM.SG.GEN gift.SG.GEN over be_surprised-ACT.PST.PTCP

sentence: Pearu sa-i oma poja peale pahase-ks.

back_translation_en: ‘Pearu is getting irritated with his daughter.’
